On a sun-baked road winding through arid plains, a caravan of eleven cloth merchants, heavy with the profits of a bustling market, journeyed homeward. Among them was the Clever Merchant, their respected Leader, whose quick wit was as renowned as his exquisite silks. As the afternoon sun beat down relentlessly, a fearsome cry split the air. From behind a thicket of thorny scrub, three burly figures emerged, the notorious robbers who styled themselves the "Three Monarchs" of the highway. With menacing clubs and glinting daggers, they ambushed the unsuspecting traders, swiftly disarming them, stripping them of their rich turbans, fine kurtas, and even their humble dhotis, leaving them bare and vulnerable on the dusty ground beside their plundered wares.

Summary:
A caravan of cloth merchants, led by the Clever Merchant, is ambushed by the boastful Three Robbers, who strip them of their goods and force them into a humiliating dance. Using a coded song, the Clever Merchant signals his fellow traders to attack, overpowering the robbers with coordinated bravery and reclaiming their stolen belongings. The merchants emerge victorious, celebrated as heroes for outwitting their oppressors and turning despair into triumph. Their tale becomes a cautionary reminder of humility and cunning.
